title: The oral microbiome is associated with HPA axis response to a psychosocial stressor
affiliations: Immune Endocrine Epigenetics Research Group, Department of Infection and Immunity, Luxembourg Institute of Health
Faculty of Science, Technology and Medicine, University of Luxembourg
Department of Psychiatry and Psychotherapy, University Medicine Greifswald
Department of Psychology, University of Cyprus
School of Medicine, National University of Ireland, Galway
Ryan Institute, National University of Galway
Division of Microbiology, National University of Galway
German Center for Cardiovascular Diseases (DZHK), Partner Site Greifswald
background: Intense psychosocial stress during early life has detrimental effects on health-disease balance in later life, and the developing microbiome contributes to long-term health.
hypotheses: The oral microbiome interacts with the stress response, modifying the effect of stress on the HPA-axis and human metabolism.
major_findings: Twelve genera exhibited an interaction with the host's cortisol-glucose response to stress, influencing cortisol and glucose release profiles and kinetics.
Diversity and evenness of the buccal microbiome interacted with glucose kinetics.
Specific taxa in the buccal and salivary microbiomes interacted with cortisol response to stress, influencing cortisol clearance.
null_findings: The salivary microbiome showed no interactions with glucose stress response.
No significant association was found between several taxa and baseline cortisol or glucose levels.
new_open_questions: What are the exact mechanisms by which the oral microbiome interacts with the HPA axis and stress response?
What is the directionality of the interaction between the microbiome and the stress response?
